timeline.content: Nichita Hristea Stănescu was born on March 31, 1933, in Ploiești, his mother being Tatiana Cereaciuchin, a member of a noble family of Russian origin who had taken refuge in Romania, and his father, Nicolae Hristea Stănescu, a former peasant turned craftsman and merchant.
Between 1944 and 1952 he attended the St. Peter and Paul High School in Ploiești (now "Mihai Viteazul"), and between 1952 and 1957 he attended the Faculty of Philology at the University of Bucharest.
In 1952, in his first year at university, he married Magdalena Petrescu, his great love as a teenager, but after only one year the two separated.

In 1955, Nichita collected his "mocking" poems, written, in his own words, "without a mother, without a father", in a volume called "Argotice - cântece la strada mare", but which would be published long after his death in 1992.
In March 1957, he makes his debut in the magazines "Tribuna" in Cluj and "Gazeta literară", where three poems are published.

In 1957 and 1958 he was briefly a proofreader and then editor of the poetry section of the "Literary Gazette", under the direction of Zaharia Stancu, and in 1960 his debut volume "The Meaning of Love" appeared.

In 1962 Nichita married the poet and essayist Doina Ciurea, and their love inspired the poet to write the book "A Vision of Feelings", which appeared two years later and for which Nichita received the Writers' Union Prize the same year.
In March 1965 he publishes the volume of poems "Right to Time", and a year later he publishes the volume "11 Elegies", published by Editura Tineretului.

In 1967, he publishes no less than three volumes - "Vertical Red", "Alpha Anthology", and the volume of poems "The Egg and the Sphere", and in 1969 he publishes the volumes of poems "Necuvintele", which again receives the Writers' Union Prize, and "A Land Called Romania". In the same year he was appointed deputy editor-in-chief of the magazine "Luceafărul", together with Adrian Păunescu.
In 1970, he publishes the volume "In the sweet classic style" and the second anthology of his work entitled "Poems" and has a monthly column in the magazine "Argeș".
Between 1970 and 1973, he became deputy editor-in-chief of the magazine "România literară", under the editorship of Nicolae Breban.

In 1971 his volumes "Belgrade in five friends" - a bilingual edition of unpublished poems - and "Nereci" ("The Unfinished Poems") are translated into the former Yugoslavia, and a year later he publishes the volume of poems "The Greatness of Cold" and receives, for the third time, the Writers' Union Prize for the volume of essays "The Book of Rereading".

In 1973 he publishes the anthology of love poems "Clear of Heart", and in 1975 he is awarded the International Johann Gottfried von Herder Prize. In the same year he publishes the anthology "Starea poeziei", for which he receives a new prize from the Writers' Union, and becomes a publicist commentator for the magazine "România literară".

During the earthquake of 4 March 1977, Nichita Stănescu tries in vain to save his friend Nicolae Ștefănescu, being hit by a collapsing wall, suffering a shock and a short-lived paralysis of the left side of his body, but which will leave him with sequelae for the rest of his life. This is also the period in which the poet became addicted to alcohol, his close relations telling him that Nichita consumed more than two bottles of vodka a day, an addiction which, it is ironic to say, did not create the drunkenness inevitable in such cases, but an almost unnatural lucidity and an artistic effervescence that led to the height of genius. It was, perhaps, the "necessary pact with the devil", without which many artists would not have reached the fulfilment of genius

In 1978, he published the volume of poems "Epica Magna", for which he received the "Mihai Eminescu" prize of the Romanian Academy, and in 1979 his volume of poems "Opere imperfecte" appeared. In the same year, he published the Bulgarian translation of the volume "Bazorelief cu innamorati", published by Narodna Kultura.

In 1980, the Swedish writer Arthur Lundkvist proposes him to the Swedish Academy for inclusion on the list of candidates for the Nobel Prize for Literature. Nichita is nominated alongside such great names as Max Frisch, Jorge Borges, Leopold Sedar Senghorn, but the winner is the Greek poet Odysseas Elytis. In 1980, the record "Nichita Stănescu - a recitation" by Constantin Crișan and Augustin Frățilă was released by Electrecord.

However, as the years went by, alcoholism would make a strong comeback in his life and would have a lasting impact on the poet's health and physiognomy. In August 1981, he suffered his first serious liver crisis, which was repeated periodically, and in the autumn he was hospitalised at Fundeni Hospital.

In 1982, he receives the "Golden Wreath" prize at the International Poetry Festival in Struga (Macedonia), and in February of the same year, the poet's father dies. Also in 1982 his volume "Knots and Signs", subtitled "Recviem for the death of his father", a selection of everything the poet has written since his last publication, appears. In July 1982 he married his last wife, Todorița Tărâță (Dora), and their love story is a truly impressive one. So much so that Dora even persuaded the poet's friends to form a kind of "anti-alcohol conspiracy", formalised in a deed on which they all signed, pledging to fight with him against the vice that had taken hold of Nichita.

On 31 March 1983, on his 50th birthday, the poet was given a national celebration, and that same year his book "The Cry of the Name" was published by Facla. On 9 December 1983, he attended a wedding of friends in Turnu Severin, but due to excessive alcohol consumption, on 12 December he suffered a severe liver crisis. He was taken by ambulance to Fundeni Hospital, but the next day, on 13 December 1983, Nichita Stănescu passed away at the age of 50. His last words were: "I'm breathing, doctor, I'm breathing". The official announcement said the poet died of cardio-respiratory arrest, but an autopsy found his liver was almost non-existent.
